title: ss2005
author: ss2005
content: Hello everyone, I’m 19 years old. I first heard about cryptocurrencies when I was around 16 or 17, as I had a lot of time while I was in school. I learned about it from an older man who was investing in Bitcoin. I haven’t heard from him since; who knows what happened. He told me to learn and research while I had the free time. Once I finish school and get a job, I won’t have time, but I will have money to invest. I will carefully read every response to my topic. I’m interested in your investments; I earn enough to set aside money each month to invest in a cryptocurrency. I don’t expect to get rich overnight, but I know I need to work, and one day I hope to reach a point where I might not have to, perhaps thanks to this investing.Please help me; this will mean a lot to me one day. Thank you to everyone who took the time to read this topic.

comments.author: Helena Yu
comments.body: If you're asking how to invest in Bitcoin, here are some guides:1. Better to make sure you have emergency funds first (this could be 6-12x of your monthly spending)2. Know which exchange that suits you, CEX if you don't care about privacy and want to make more profit or No KYC P2P/DEX if you care with privacy and don't mind to spend extra, check kynot.me3. Know basic digital security and how to use Bitcoin wallet [GUIDE] How to Safely Download and Verify Electrum [Guide]4. The last one is learn how you save your seed phrase.But, if you're asking how to get rich, my answer is none. There's no secret or ways to get rich.There's a person living with frugal lifestyle, he always try to learn new skill, invest as much as possible, but he lack of relations which make him can't find high salary jobs because not all jobs are posted in jobs portal, so no one will recommend him.There's a person with moderate lifestyle, he invest quite much and spend some of his money to get more relations. Now he work in high salary jobs because of a friend recommend him, he choose to resign and open a business. Unfortunately his business failed and he need to start from zero.There's a person with low education and only work in blue collar jobs, he didn't invest a lot, but he choose to buy lottery ticket. Surprisingly he won and he got $1 Million, then he resign and start a business, now he's successful.It's all about luck.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Since you have age on your side and not finding get rich quick You can adopt DCA Dollar cost average i.e investing same amount whether weekly daily or monthly depemfJust be consistent. Since you interested in holding, I would recommend a non custodial wallet(You can try Bluewallet or Ethereum ) or if you have the fund try a Good hardware wallet (Note I wouldn't advice on Trevor and ledger). You can learn to secure your wallet and how to make transactions. Since you starting you can use CEX to buy and transfer to your Non custodial wallet to hold. You can check some of the links shared above.

comments.author: lovesmayfamilis
comments.body: The correct step at this time you have already taken is to come to this forum. Your age will be a good assistant in investing in Bitcoin. Start studying the forum; do not hesitate to ask any questions that are not clear to you. Do not rush too much with the desire to buy bitcoin; try to find out how to store bitcoins, in which wallet it will be more convenient for you to do this, and also learn the DCA strategy so that your investments acquire regular investments for a long period. Being patient, you can create additional capital for yourself after some time.

comments.author: Trilli7777
comments.body: I'm happy you know that investing in Bitcoin is not a get rich quick scheme I myself recently started I was into alt cryptocurrencies before, but I had the opportunity to meet someone who taught and told me a lot about Bitcoin Now I'm also very happy you are starting young. I wish I knew better back then. I would have started in the early days I would advise you to take your time to research more about Bitcoin. It's not just about buying Bitcoin. There's more to it, so I was toldTry to understand how it works, risks involved,how to save you seed phrase, the list is endless I know this may sound unnecessarily stressful, but I believe this forum will come in handy in that aspect I have been going through the forum during my free time and actually found a lot of interesting topics that have helped For instance, I saw a topic talking about how a person was scammed. I had no idea someone could be scammed that way ( from an online account)You could also try reading some books on it Most importantly, don't use all of your income. Use an amount you don't need at the moment As my friend will always say, investing is a marathon, not a raceI wish you good luck on this journey you are about to embark

You also have an advantage since you have a good job that can make you save and buy Bitcoin. You should have an emergency fund depending on your expenses for like three to six months. You should also diversify your income to enable you to have a more financial backup. Use a monthly DCA strategy to accumulate your coins and be patient to wait for your investment to grow. Bitcoin has a four-year investment cycle but you can decide to keep it for more years.But you should know that using the terms Bitcoin and cryptocurrency interchangeably is wrong. Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency and there are others called altcoins. I will advice you as a newbie to focus only on Bitcoin until you have understood the complex and highly risky field of altcoins.

comments.author: TheUltraElite
comments.body: You should give time to your studies because that will help your secure a degree and get a job. That job and its income acts as the cushion during bad times in bitcoin, it is equally important if not more. Whatever you are earning now, I dont know but that should be kept for fiat savings. Once that exceeds only then go for bitcoin. When emergencies hit, you will not have the time nor the hardware needed to get fiat and solve the problem.Once you have that you start learning about how the system works and about wallet software, how to keep your devices safe and so on. In the meantime check out your local laws regarding bitcoin and how the community is in your country with bitcoin.Eventually as you start earning, allocate monthly amounts to buy bitcoin but hold on to it if the price is too high. Depending on your mileage, you will have to target accumulating bitcoin monthly or yearly.

comments.author: tabas
comments.body: I like what you've said about not getting rich overnight. That's the first thing that you need to set to your mind because too many newbies are being misled by their own thoughts that when invested in Bitcoin, expect tremendous gain so fast. As you are still studying right now, all you have to do is focus on your studies and if you want to read some things about Bitcoin, maybe a few hours or times of browsing here is quite fine. As long as it doesn't harm your studies, you're good. Once decide to put some money to invest monthly or anytime you wish, just do it and you don't need someone to do it for you but only to guide you like which wallets you're going to use and what exchange is supported in your country. Because that's where the risk comes, when you are asking for help and that person gives you specifics of which wallet to download but it's not from an official website, be observant and always check the resources where you are downloading from for your wallet. For example, use electrum. We've got an official website for that through bitcoin.org.

comments.author: Text
comments.body: Hey there! It’s awesome to see someone your age with such a long-term mindset and curiosity about investing. Your approach to learning now and taking it slow with realistic expectations is solid, trust me, that's a huge part of successful investing.Since you’re already familiar with Bitcoin, you could consider dollar-cost averaging (DCA) into it, meaning you’d invest a set amount each month, regardless of price. This strategy can help you avoid trying to time the market and keeps you invested without stressing over every price move. Over time, BTC has shown resilience, but as you probably know, it’s important to only invest what you can afford to hold long-term, especially with the crypto market’s ups and downs.Wishing you the best on this journey! You’re setting yourself up with a strong foundation, keep it up!

Thank you to everyone who took the time to read this topic.Hi.Since everyone else is talking about how you can make investments or learn about it, I would like to provide you with some warnings and things that you need to know and understand as you delve into this world of cryptocurrencies and online financial markets. There is no doubt that there are a lot of lucrative earning opportunities available online, cryptocurrencies being one of the most trending ones at the moment, but you need to understand that nothing comes easy in this world. So there are certain things you need to understand to stay safe in this world.The very first thing is to understand how you can safeguard your funds when you start buying Bitcoin or any other cryptocurrencies. You have already received suggestions about wallets, you can use a non-custodial wallet at first such as Electrum, and later when you see your funds are getting higher, you should switch to a hardware wallet which is generally safer.The second and most important thing is to never trust anyone you meet online. The online universe is full of scammers and scumbags who are always looking for prey and you wouldn't want to be their target. Don't talk to anyone, especially about what you are doing and that you have money, and, never open links or download any apps or games on the device where you are keeping your cryptocurrencies. People use malware and viruses to get access to your funds.

Honestly a lot better than when I was 19. First things first, I'd remove any sort of unrealistic expectations with trading. Even people who've traded for years may not necessarily have to not work after a few years. Just do and think what you can do for now. Next is just the basics. Wallets, streamlined processes to buy, thinking about fees and stuff like that. Personally I'd say it's a good time ish to start since the market is expected to go 100k by next year. Maybe decide then and there whether you're going to sell out after that and then just start the DCA again when the price dumps down, or just continue. Former you can take some immediate profit, latter makes you stable but you probably wouldn't profit for the next couple of years.
